Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The striatum in the evolution of flexibile, learned vocal communication

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite numerous hypotheses concerning language evolution, the neurobiological origins of the human capacity to speak remain little understood. Studies suggest that the striatum, a subcortical structure forming complex connections with the cerebral cortex, may be important in the evolution of vocal learning - the capacity to modify vocalizations in response to social experience - which is necessary to acquire speech during development. The striatum also is a key site of expression of FOXP2, a gene that underwent positive selection in modern humans, and, in a mutated form, is responsible for a hereditary disorder affecting language production. To date, however, evidence indicating a role of the striatum in the evolution of speech and language mainly comes from experimental species, such as birds and mice, which are evolutionarily distant from humans.

The aim of the current project by doctoral student Serena Bianchi (George Washington University), under the guidance of Dr. Chet Sherwood, is to identify neural features of the non-human primate striatum that may have been associated with the evolution of the capacity for vocal learning that characterizes human speech. To this end, this project uses non-invasive neuroimaging techniques, and post-mortem histological and molecular analyses, to examine the striatum of captive chimpanzees for which the use of learned, voluntarily controlled vocalizations produced to attract the attention of the experimenter (attention-getting vocalizations) has been documented. Specific aims include assessing whether the striatum of chimpanzees who produce attention-getting vocalizations differs from chimpanzees that do not exhibit this vocal phenotype in 1) morphology, and pattern of connections with motor and language-related regions of the cerebral cortex; and 2) neuronal plasticity and expression of proteins associated with synaptic functions and FOXP2. Investigating the neurobiology of vocal communication in an animal model evolutionarily close to humans may help identify precursors to speech production within a Darwinian framework of language origins as 'descent with modifications' of existing neural structures in the non-human primate brain.

As part of this project, dissemination of knowledge about the evolution of the brain and language will be fostered through collaboration with the outreach program of the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, and the development of on-line resources and teaching materials. In addition, the histological collection created by this project will be made available to other researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Whereas most animals communicate through innate vocalizations, the main mode of auditory-vocal communication of humans, speech, is learned during development through social contact with family members, peers, and other individuals. The capacity to acquire and modulate new sounds heard from the environment, or vocal learning, is relatively rare in the animal kingdom, and has been described in few species of birds, cetaceans, and bats. Among primates, humans are the only species that shows such sophisticated motor control over their vocalizations.

The goal of this project was therefore to investigate the neurobiological origins of the capacity for vocal learning in a primate species. In order to do so, we examined brains of captive chimpanzees which had been shown to be able to voluntarily produce atypical, learned sounds to attract the attention of the experimenter (e.g. raspberries, extended grunts), and compared them with the brain of chimpanzees from the same population that never displayed this capacity. These experiments employed a variety of methodologies, including in vivo, noninvasive neuroimaging techniques (Magnetic Resonance Imaging, MRI; Diffusion Tensor imaging, DTI), and histological and molecular analyses of post-mortem tissue. All methodologies were non-invasive, and postmortem tissue had been previously collected from individuals who died naturally for reasons unrelated to the current project.

Aims included identifying structural differences at the 1) macroscopic and 2) microscopic level (reflecting neuronal integration and gene expression).  A particular focus of this project was on the striatum, a structure of the brain that is involved in motor control, and has been suggested to play a role in the evolution of speech and language (e.g., Lieberman 2002; Enard 2011) .  

Results suggested that chimpanzees that produce atypical sounds display trends for brain anatomical differences from those who do not produce atypical sounds in regions involved in motor control, including the striatum. No differences at the microscopic level in striatum for a measure of neuronal integration were found, although molecular analyses indicated a trend for increased expression of a marker associated with synaptic plasticity, and of FOXP2, a transcription factor involved in speech functions in humans.

This research contributed to elucidating the neuroanatomical underpinnings of flexible vocal communication in chimpanzees, and, by examining the neural bases of vocal production in a great ape species, it promoted the study of a nonhuman primate model of vocal learning, which is just started to being investigated. As the fossil record of the vocal behavior of human ancestors are scant, a better understanding of the vocal capacities of great apes remains one key avenue to shed light on the origins of speech in humans.

 

This project was finalized in a Ph.D. dissertation, which allowed the co-PI to complete her doctoral training. As part of this project, undergraduates were shown how to examine and quantify neuroanatomical features at the microscope, and were exposed to histological preparation of specimens. Findings of this research have been disseminated at scientific conferences, and are in the process of being submitted for publication in academic journals. 

 

Works cited:

Enard W. 2011. FOXP2 and the role of cortico-basal ganglia circuits in speech and language evolution. Curr. Op. Neurobiol. 21:415–424. 

Lieberman P. 2002. On the nature and evolution of the neural bases of human language. Am. J. Phys. Anthropol. 119:36–62.
